ok namban (or even Hizen) to me. Being smallish in size and with that well-=
rounded edge, I wonder if this might be Satsuma work. Just a gut-feeling gu=
ess.  

Ron

  Jim Gilbert wrote:

  > Rich,
  > Pieces like tha=
t seem to have been used to change the shape of the 
  > seppa dai to accom=
modate a certain shape and/or size of saya and 
  > tsuka.  There are tsuba=
 where the seppa dai has been enlarged by 
  > fitting pieces all of the wa=
y around.  Sometimes various pieces 
  > (including the more common hitsuan=
a plugs) are inserted by a later 
  > collector to restore the look of the =
guard to something like what he 
  > believes to be its original state.
  >=

  > I could imagine a piece like being inserted to repair damage if it 
  =
> were somewhere else on the guard.  It's hard to imagine how that 
  > par=
ticular spot would be damaged. 
  >
  > I have seen a fair number of tsuba =
that have a pronounced asymmetry to 
  > the shape of the seppa dai in that=
 location.  There is metal "missing" 
  > from the same position at the upp=
er right.  My guess is that at some 
  > time and/or place a slightly asymm=
etrical tsuka or saya shape was in 
  > style and that tsuba were either ma=
de or modified to accommodate that 
  > shape.  I haven't come across such =
a koshirae and not being a sword 
  > user I can't guess as to why such a s=
hape might be desirable. 
  >
  > The insert on your guard might be an atte=
mpt to change one of these 
  > tsuba to the more common symmetrical oval s=
hape.
  >
  > Any other ideas?
  >
  > Jim
